comment._content: Commissioned into the Territorial Infantry (unattached) on 29th August 1912, Charles Alexander Kenneth Anderson is appointed to the Cambridge University, Senior Division, Officer Training Corps, as an unattached Territorial Army Officer, with effect 16th January 1913, [London Gazette of 7 Feb 13]. His commemoration on the Menin Gate is at Panel 51 and 53. There is a photograph of him in his Glengarry at www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=108256... 1st Royal Scots Fusiliers were in 9th Infantry Brigade. On 12th November 1914 the Brigade Headquarters was shelled by German artillery and the Brigade Commander, Brigadier Frederick Charles Shaw, was badly wounded.//

comment._content:
From Internet Archive's 
Full text of 
HARROW MEMORIALS 
OF THE GREAT WAR 
VOLUME 1
AUGUST 23rd, 1914, to MARCH 20th, 1915 
2ND LIEUTENANT CHARLES ALEXANDER KENNETH ANDERSON 
King's Royal Rifle Corps 
Church Hill oy'-ii' Aged 21 Not. 12th, 191 4 

Only son of Alexander Richard Anderson, F.R.C.S., Senior Surgeon 
General Hospital, Nottingham, and of Edith, daughter of the late Charles 
Edward Tuck, J. P., Blofield, Norfolk, and grandson of the late Colonel 
Richard Anderson, H.M. ^6th Regiment. 

Pembroke College, Cambridge. 

2nd Lieutenant Anderson received his Commission in the Royal Scots 
Fusiliers on the day War was declared, and a week later joined his Regiment 
at Gosport, leaving for the Front on August 13th, 19 14. He was trans- 
ferred to the I St Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps on August 14th, but 
continued to serve with the Scots Fusiliers until his death. 

He took part in the Retreat from Mons, and in the battles of Le Cateau, 
the Marne, the Aisne, and the ist Battle of Ypres, in which he was slightly 
wounded. He was killed leading his men in a night attack on the German 
trenches at Chateau Haerentage, on November 12th. He had outlived or 
outstayed nearly all his brother-officers. Of the number that left Gosport 
with the Regiment only three remained. 

Colonel (now Major-General) Douglas Smith, then commanding the 
Regiment, writes: — 

"A capital boy in every sense of the word. Always cheerful and ready 
to work, and thoroughly reliable. He did not know what fear meant, and 
was so eager to undertake anything that was going." 

Captain A. A. Seaton, Tutor and History Lecturer of Pembroke College, 
who has since died of wounds, writes : — 

"He stands out in my mind as one of the most lovable of my pupils, 
and of the many men serving at the Front, I do not think there is one whose 
death could touch me so nearly." 

Another Cambridge letter contains the following: — 

"We felt it all the more because Mr. M told us he had run up 

against Anderson in the road on the Retreat from Mons. He said he was 
very mud-stained and dirty, but smiling as serenely as ever."
